dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Range Description
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Lansdown, R.V., Knees, S.G. & Patzelt, A. 2013. Bacopa monnieri. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Bacopa monnieri is distributed in tropics and subtropics of the world: in Sri Lanka, India, Nepal, China, Taiwan, Viet Nam and Pakistan. It is also found in Florida, Hawaii and southern states of USA and the Meditearranean Basin.

In India it is found in Andaman, Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Delhi, Goa, Gujarat, Kerala, Karnataka, Manipur, Orissa, Punjab, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal.

In the Arabian Peninsula, this species has been recorded from Bahrain, Kuwait, northern and southern Oman, UAE, Saudi Arabia and Yemen including Socotra. It occurs throughout the southern and western Peninsula.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObjects.title: Description
dataObjects.rightsHolder: Missouri Botanical Garden, 4344 Shaw Boulevard, St. Louis, MO, 63110 USA
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Flora of China Vol. 18: 21 in eFloras.org, Missouri Botanical Garden. Accessed Nov 12, 2008.
dataObjects.description: Stems creeping, rooting at nodes, succulent, glabrous. Leaves sessile, oblong-oblanceolate, 0.8-2 cm X 3-6 mm, margin entire or rarely dentate, apex rounded. Flowers axillary. Pedicel 0.5-3.5 cm. Bracteoles 2, linear, below calyx. Sepals 5, ca. 5 mm; lower and upper sepals ovate-lanceolate; lateral 2 sepals lanceolate to linear. Corolla blue, purple, or white, 8-10 mm, obscurely 2-lipped. Stamens didynamous. Stigma capitate. Capsule narrowly ovoid, enveloped in persistent calyx, apex acute. Seeds yellow-brown, ellipsoid, truncate at one end, longitudinally striate. Fl. May-Oct.

agents.full_name: Wu Zhengyi, Peter H. Raven & Hong Deyuan

dataObjects.title: Herb-of-grace (Bacopa monnieri)
dataObjects.description: I photograph this species every few months as it's one of my favorites. Semi-aquatic, it grows in mats in moist areas and right along the edge of (and into) lakes and ponds. You may call her Water hyssop, Brahmi, Herb-of-grace or several other names. There are many medicinal uses for this tiny plant! The blossom above is about 10mm across so if you can't find them, you may be standing on them! These live by a pond in the south section of Juno Dunes Natural Area, Juno Beach, Florida.  en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacopa_monnieri

dataObjects.location: Hawaii, Kanaha Beach stream outlet, Maui

dataObjects.title: Bacopa monnieri
dataObjects.description: ʻAeʻae or Water hyssop Plantaginaceae (Plantain family) Indigenous to the Hawaiian Islands Oʻahu (Cultivated)  The whole herb is used medicinally in India in a variety of ways. It is grown as a medicinal crop and is being research for antioxidant properties, to help the nervous system, and to improve memory and mental functions.   nativeplants.hawaii.edu/plant/view/Bacopa_monnieri

dataObjects.title: Water hyssop (Bacopa monnieri)
dataObjects.description: Face to face with the herb of grace. One of my favorite little micro-plants, water hyssop, at Juno Dunes Natural Area, growing along a wet trail. There is some debate as to the native status of this little herb but, despite having a Sanskrit name (Brahmi), it has been in North America as long as anyone can remember so it's probably pan-tropical. This little plant has a phenomenal variety of medicinal uses and has been utilized from ancient times right up to the present. I can't begin to list them all but uses include improving memory, antioxidant properties, a tranquillizer, muscle relaxant, anti-anxiety and anti-depressant. These seemed to have a slightly bluer tint than the ones I photographed a few months ago.

dataObjects.title: Ischnura ramburii
dataObjects.description: Rambur's Forktail Coenagrionidae (Narrow-winged Damselflies) Introduced to the Hawaiian Islands c.1973 Man-made ponds in Mililani, Oʻahu (elevation 865 ft.)  A male resting on ʻAeʻae or Water hyssop (Bacopa monnieri), an indigenous plant to the islands.  nativeplants.hawaii.edu/plant/view/Bacopa_monnieri
